patient_information: Age: 43 years Sex: male Travel history: recent trip to Mozambique and Chile Medical history: unremarkable
chief_complaint: fever for the past 3 days, recurrent fever for the past 7 days
history_of_present_illness: 43-year-old male presents with a 3-day history of high fever. He has recently returned from a 5-week trip to Mozambique and Chile. He did not take any antimalarial chemoprophylaxis, but he took standby emergency treatment for presumed malaria when feeling febrile about 3 weeks ago.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel history: recent trip to Mozambique and Chile Freshwater contact: reports freshwater contact in a small lake near Maputo
vitals: Temperature: 39.8°C (103.6°F) Other vitals not reported: no other vital signs reported
physical_exam: General findings: 43-year-old male, febrile Specific systems: normal physical examination with no rash, no hepatomegaly, no splenomegaly and no lymphadenopathy
labs_and_diagnostics: Cbc: elevated eosinophils (2.1 × 10^9/L), normal total white cell count Liver enzymes: slightly elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) C-reactive protein (crp): slightly raised Chest radiography: {"description": "some nodular lesions ranging in size from 2 to 5mm in the periphery of the lower lung zones bilaterally", "confirmation": "confirmed by a CT scan of his chest"}
differential_diagnosis: {'name': 'Acute Schistosomiasis (Katayama Syndrome)', 'evidence': 'elevated eosinophils, elevated liver enzymes, nodular changes in the periphery of the lower lung zones on chest radiography'}; {'name': 'Typhoid Fever', 'reasons_for_exclusion': ['eosinopenia (not eosinophilia)', 'no history of recent travel to endemic areas for typhoid fever']}; {'name': 'Amoebic Liver Abscess', 'reasons_for_exclusion': ['no history of recent travel to endemic areas for amoebic liver abscess', 'no evidence of abdominal pain or other symptoms suggestive of an abscess']}
management_and_clinical_course: Treatment: treated with praziquantel Response to treatment: clinical improvement, full recovery by day 6 Complications: no complications documented
final_diagnosis: Name: Acute Schistosomiasis (Katayama Syndrome) Confirmation method: positive antischistosomal antibodies and Schistosoma mansoni ova found in stool sample Evidence: ["elevated eosinophils, elevated liver enzymes, nodular changes in the periphery of the lower lung zones on chest radiography"] Exclusion of alternatives: [{"name": "Typhoid Fever", "reasons_for_exclusion": ["eosinopenia (not eosinophilia)", "no history of recent travel to endemic areas for typhoid fever"]}, {"name": "Amoebic Liver Abscess", "reasons_for_exclusion": ["no history of recent travel to endemic areas for amoebic liver abscess", "no evidence of abdominal pain or other symptoms suggestive of an abscess"]}]
